Description: An animal-shaped spout, broken from a terracotta vessel, apparently the head of a harnessed horse, but very stylized, with a long tubular muzzle acting as a spout: possibly a cockerel's head. The basic head was wheel-thrown, with a domed end; the muzzle was hand-modelled and applied. The eyes are rounded knobs of clay added to the head, the eyeballs defined by the use of a tubular tool; the small ears were pinched-out. The crossover harness was then applied. Red Nile silt with a grey core and some white inclusions, the outside covered overall with a cream-coloured slip; red-brown fired-on ceramic colours on the harness, eyes and ears.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: Byzantine Research and Publication Fund (BRPF). Excavated by R. Campbell Thompson and F.A. Richards in 1913-14 at Wadi Sarga, 15 miles south of Asyut. [The same as registration no. 1919,0505.316.] Late Roman, about AD 550-650. Comparandum: Near Petrie Museum uc48345, from Memphis.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3734)
